channel.title: Yocto Course
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian

item.title: Exercise 1 : Meet Poky
item.description:
Meet poky
Learn commands to build an image.
Run an image.


Poky is the reference distribution of the Yocto Project which uses OpenEmbedded build system Technology.
It is a toolset for building embedded linux systems.
Its made up of
1. Collection of tools
2. Configuration files
3. Recipe Data a.k.a metadata
 Key features include
1. flexible configuration,
2. support for cross compilation using bitbake-tool.
3. ability to generate minimal and optimized system images.


In this Virtual Machine(VM), Poky is available at ~/work/poky/poky.
Start by cd ~/work/poky/poky.


Find the script oe-init-build-env, can you identify what type of license it has and how it is called?

hint
Just try to read the first few lines of this script. It's a complex script, don't let it bother you.        Answer    This script is to be called `./oe-init-build-env builddir` and the license is `GPL-2.0`
What happens when you source this file?

hint
What does the name indicate?        Answer    The sourcing creates the build environment, the configuration files and switches us to the build directory.
Can you Note down the names of the images that start with core-image on a piece of paper. We will use this later.

hint
pay special attention to the names core-image-*        Answer  - we see the images : `core-image-minimal`, `core-image-full-cmdline`, `core-image-weston` and so on when we source the script.
We are now inside the build directory, apart from creating the build directory, several configuration files (confs) have been created. Can you find the conf file with the largest code length?

hint
- You can use find . -name "*.conf" to find all the conf files inside a specific directory
- Use wc to find word count for the files
- Pro tip: use xargs if possible to combine find and wc.        Answer     `local.conf` is the file

Choose the one with the largest lines and try to read through the comments. The file is very often used and is very well documented, don't let it overwhelm you.

Can you identify what Distribution DISTRO it is using?
and what is the architecture of the MACHINE that is being built?

hint
- Check the DISTRO Variable and see what it is set for distribution
- Look at the MACHINE variable maybe there is a clue to what architecture we are building.        Answer     - Distribution can be found from the `DISTRO` variable which is set to "poky"     - The architecture being built can be found from the `MACHINE` variable which is set to `qemux86-64`
Can you see if we have supported debugging tools like gdb in this build?

hint
- Reading the comments above EXTRA_IMAGE_FEATURES could give you an idea.        Answer   - Debugging tools are not enabled. `tools-debug` add support for gdb and other debugging tools.

Bitbake our build system is part of the yocto project and is used to build images. We can now start building a simple image and see what happens.

Can you try to build the core-image-minimal image?

hint
-Bitbake our build system, can build an image just like this bitbake Image_name.        Answer   - `bitbake core-image-minimal`
Now lets try to build another image
bitbake core-image-full-cmdline

Do you see a lot of things going on? Does it make your head spin? Don't worry we will cover all this later in this course? Does it go faster or slower?

For now, try to find these images, they have a format .ext4 and they are somewhere inside the build directory.

hint
You can use find . -name "core-image*.ext4" to find the file, from which you can infer the directory.


Answer
- You can find the output images here /home/yocto/work/poky/poky/build/tmp/deploy/images/qemux86-64
   

Now that you have built the images, its time to see what they look like.
Open terminal, you can find it in the VM, and try to split the terminal window to left and right
10. On the left window, try to run the core-image-minimal and on the right window run core-image-full-cmdline. Maybe we can use QEMU somehow..
what command can we use?

hint
At its simplest form you can use qemu by runqemu image_name


Answer
- Use runqemu core-image-minimal on the left
- Use runqemu core-image-full-cmdline on the right



Use root as password for login.

Congratulations, now you have both the images running. Now its time to see what's the difference between them.
11. Can you check what applications are installed inside both the instances?

hint
You can check the installed applications under bin directory


Answer
- ls /usr/bin
    Can you find any common programs in both? ## Part 6 : Exploring the QEMU hardware 12. You have now successfully booted into the prebuilt image, can you find out how much memory and processor cores are present in the image?         hint     - Use the command `free` to find the memory     - Use the command `nproc` to find the processors     ## Part 7 Exiting the QEMU

use CTRL + A+ X to exit qemu*

item.title: Exercise 2: Make
item.description:
Make is an automation tool that is often used to improve the build process.
Makefiles exists to help decide which part of a large program needs to be recompiled.


Refresher for the syntax of Make
Learn how to build Makefile to automate the bitbake processes

Composed of set of rules and a rule looks like :
targets: prerequisites command command command


Start by going to /~/Downloads/Exercise2 this is where the source code is located.
For this part refer to q1 folder.

Usually a Makefile is named as "Makefile" or "makefile", now we have a problem.
Can you figure out how to run this file?

hint
How do you force a make file? Maybe there's a flag?        Answer    You can read a file as make file by using the `-f` flag.    `make -f notamakefile.mk`


Makefiles can also be used to build kernel modules in linux.
Check the folder q2, in this example, we have a file yocto_driver.c and a makefile Makefile. Luckily this makefile is correct, so its all about calling the correct target.
There are three targets : one prints the messages, one builds the yocto_driver and one cleans it up. Can you run them one by one?

hint
You can run a target by using make target        Answer  The targets are `hello`, `build_kernel_module`,`clean`. Try to use make with it.

There is an error here, I lied.
yocto_driver.c has some code commented out, maybe the comments have some clues?
   
hint
Makefile is okay, its the c code thats buggy. Read the comments
       Answer - Uncomment the first three commented lines LICENSE, AUTHOR and DESCRIPTION. - Uncomment the last line and change the argument to yocto_driver_exit instead of robot_driver_exit


In this segment we will see how a make file could be used in yocto.
The question Q3-Q6 have some instructions and hints embedded in them.


How did you build your image in the exercise 1? You used 'bitbake core-image-minimal' right?, Make can automate this for you so you don't have to do it manually!!
In this exercise, we will create two targets one to build the image and the other to clean.
Remember you need to source oe-init-build-env too!

Open q3 folder and explore the makefile inside it. The goal is to build the two targets.
Answers are available in the solution folder for reference.


By same logic, we could also run QEMU using a makefile instead, open q4 and see what it requires!


Can you try to run toaster from here?

How can you use make to restart toaster ?


Yocto is also used for complex stuff, this is a sneak peak to what's coming next!

Go through the hints, if too difficult take look at the answer which is found in the solutions folder!
Note: These are preliminary examples, you could make make files to suit even complex needs!


https://makefiletutorial.com/

item.title: Exercise : Bitbake
item.description:
Understanding the difference with Make
Getting comfortable with Bitbake Syntax.


Understanding BitBake variable syntax is crucial for configuring and controlling the build process in the Yocto Project.
Bitbake syntax is similar to Make, however there are some nuances.


A very simple assignment. A = "Hej \ Hola \ Salut \ "    
 If i print A, how many lines would it contain?
   
hint
What does the " \ " operator really mean?
       Answer    Its just one line, \ just treats the text as if they are next to each other.

 Expanding Variables   B = "Yocto" C = "Embedded" D = "{B}{C}" B = "Open" E = "D{C}"
  Question: What is the value of D & E?
   
hint
- Is the value of B Assigned in line 1 or line 4?
- Are you paying attention to the braces.
       Answer - B will be assigned to Open in line 4, so D will use that value and is expanded to "OpenEmbedded" - With *E* the trick is to pay attention, the *D* doesn't have curly braces, so it is not expanded. The output would be DEmbedded.

Default Values (?=)
CANDY? ="Licorice" FIKA = "Kanelbulle" CANDY = "M&M" DRINK ?= "COFFEE" DRINK ?= "TEA" FIKA ?= "Pan au chocolat"
   
Question: I would drink _ with my _ while munching _
   
hint
When is a default value assigned?

   
Answer
A default value is assigned when it is empty.
CANDY is assigned a value "M&M"
DRINK takes on the first value which is "COFFEE"
FIKA is of course "Kanelbulle"
 


Weak defaults (??=)
 
SUMMER??="JULY" WINTER="DECEMBER" VACATION??="MARCH" SUMMER??="AUGUST" WINTER??="FEBRUARY"
  Question : When is SUMMER and WINTER?
   
hint
Note: This expands immediately when empty and also replaces previous  weak defaults values

   
Answer
- Weak defaults can replace previous default, so SUMMER is now 'AUGUST'
- WINTER is set as DECEMBER initially and stay the same.
- VACATION is ofcourse MARCH.
 



Immediate expansion and Appends
C = "Summery" A :="Hello ${C}" C = "Wintery" A +="Sweden" B ="Hello" B .="OpenEmbedded"
   Question: What is the value of A and B?
   

hint
Are all appends same? Are all assignment same?

 
Answer
- A is initially assigned the value Hello Summery
- Then "Sweden" is appended to A with a space so A become "Hello Summery Sweden"
- B is initially assigned Hello and is appended without spaces, so it become "HelloOpenEmbedded"


Overrides Style Syntax (append and prepend)
MACHINE = "intel" MACHINE:append = "amd" MACHINE2 ="amd" MACHINE2:prepend ="intel " MACHINE3 ="intel amd" MACHINE4 ="intelamd" MACHINE5 = "intel amd "
  Question : Which machines are the same?
   
hint
How does override syntax work?

   
Answer

MACHINE and MACHINE 4 are the same
MACHINE 2 and MACHINE 3 are the same  

Removal
HERO = "Romeo" AUTHOR = "Shakespeare" AUTHOR:prepend = "William-" REMOVE_HERO ="Macbeth Othello" HERO +="Antonio" HERO +="Balthasar" HERO +="Othello" HERO +="Macbeth" HERO:remove = "$REMOVE_HERO" REMOVE_HERO ="Macbeth Balthasar"
   
Question: What is the name of the Author and who are the heros?
   
hint
is remove immediate or does it wait for the variable to be set?

   
Answer
- the variable is set to the last value macbeth balthasar and these are removed from hereos.
- AUTHOR Is ofcourse "William-Shakespeare"


Override vs normal
  Consider a BBCLASS, a class.
//FRUIT.bbclass FRUIT1 +="TOMATO" FRUIT2:append = " TOMATO"
Actual code
inherit FRUIT FRUIT1 = "Durian" FRUIT2 = "Durian"
Are fruit 1 and fruit 2 same?
   
hint
Override syntax guarantees an operation

   
Answer
- No They are not
- FRUIT1 is set to DURIAN
- FRUIT2 is set to Durian TOMATO



Overrides
OVERRIDES="fruit:french:food" HELLO = "How are you doing?" HELLO:french ="Comment ça va?" B="HELLO" C="${HELLO}"
 Question: What is the value of B and C?
   
hint
How does OVERRIDES affect metadata?

   
Answer
- When OVERRIDES variable is set, it changes the metadata. So now HELLO is overriden to HELLO:french , so the value of C is "Comment Ca va?"
- B is HELLO


Overrides with appends
OVERRIDES="qemu:qemux86-64:arm:qemux86" SUPPORTED_MACHINES ="intel" UNSUPPORTED_MACHINES="amd" SUPPORTED_MACHINES:append:qemux86 ="qemux86" UNSUPPORTED_MACHINES:append:intel="intel"
   
Question: What is the value of SUPPORTED_MACHINES and UNSUPPORTED_MACHINES?
   
hint
Are all the overrides set?

   
Answer
- SUPPORTED machines will be "intelqemux86"
- UNSUPPORTED machines will be amd because the override "intel" is not set in the OVERRIDES variable!
 


Appends and prepends
DEPENDS ="vim gcc python" OVERRIDES ="vscode:powerpoint:paint" DEPENDS:append:vscode =" .NET3.5" DEPEMDS:prepend:vscode =".NET Core "
   
Question : What is the value of DEPENDS if we use the override VSCODE?
   
hint
Are you paying attention?

   
Answer

DEPENDS is just appended, prepend is a farce.
So the output would be "vim gcc python .NET3.5"
 


Multiple overrides DEPENDS = "vim bash nano" DEPENDS:vscode= ".net-core bash" DEPENDS:powerpoint=".net-core" DEPENDS:pages="swift xcode" DEPENDS:virutalbox="windows"
    What would be the value of DEPENDS?
    1. If override is set?
   
Answer

Depends on the OVERRIDES Variable. 
   2. If override is not set?
   
Answer

It would be "vim bash nano"


Okay, now that you are familiar with Bitbake syntax, there is one final puzzle to crack!!
OVERRIDES= ":germen:" SUMMARY = "Mystery Package" DESCRIPTION = "A mysterious package" LICENSE = "MIT" DECRYPT_LOGIC="Shift right by 1" INITIAL_CODE:= "GDKKN" SRC_URI ?= "https://github.com/sridharsabarish/yocto/blob/main/General%20Resources/quiz.md" SRC_URI ??= "https://github.com/sridharsabarish/yocto/blob/main/General%20Resources/cheatsheet2.md" SRC_URI = "https://github.com/sridharsabarish/yocto/blob/main/General%20Resources/cheatsheet.md" SUMMARY .= "s" DESCRIPTION +="that could change the " WORLD ="WORLD" WORLD:german ="WELT" DESCRIPTION .="${WORLD}" CRACKED_CODE ="$(WORLD)" INITIAL_CODE+= "VNQKC" CRACKED_CODE:prepend="HELLO "
Questions:
13. What is the value of SRC_URI?
   
Answer
- Assignment trumps all the defaults
- It is set
SRC_URI ="https://github.com/sridharsabarish/yocto/blob/main/General%20Resources/cheatsheet.md"
 


What is the DESCRIPTION?
   
Answer
- Description is initially set to "A mysterious package", then the words are added with space and then the value of $WORLD is added without space
- This makes it "A mysterious package that could change the WORLD" as "german" is not set in the OVERRIDES variable!
 


Is CRACKED_CODE the cesar's cipher (right shifted version) of the INITIAL_CODE?
   
Answer
- Yes!
- CRacked code is "HELLO WORLD"
- Initial Code is "GDKKN VNQKC"
- Add one to all characters and you get the cracked code!
 


For the entire exercise, you can refer to

Bitbake Syntax

item.title: Exercise: Explore Metadata and Recipes
item.description:
Explore metadata and intro to recipes
Understand what components make up a recipe.
Understand how data is shared between recipes
Explore conf.


A key element of the Yocto Project is the meta-data which is used to construct a Linux distribution, contained in the files that the build system parses when building an image.
In general, Metadata includes recipes, configuration files and other information referring to the build instructions themselves, as well as the data used to control what things get built and to affect how they are built.
The meta-data also includes commands and data used to indicate what versions of software are used, and where they are obtained from, as well as changes or additions to the software itself (patches or auxiliary files) which are used to fix bugs or customize the software for use in a particular situation.
OpenEmbedded Core is an important set of validated metadata.


Recipes .bb and extensions .bbappend
Classes .bbclass
Include Files .inc
Configuration files .conf


Files that have the .bb suffix are “recipes” files.
In general, a recipe contains information about a single piece of software.
This information includes the location from which to download the unaltered source, any source patches to be applied to that source (if needed), which special configuration options to apply, how to compile the source files, and how to package the compiled output.

Identify the recipe in the bunch of these file. Can you guess the tasks that this recipe will do?
   
hint
- What extension does the recipe have?
- Tasks look like functions what reminds you of a function?

   
Answer
The recipe is xyz.bb and the functions are cast_configuration_spell(), brew_potion, apply_protective_charm, display_wizard_title, banish_unwanted and theres one more!


This recipe performs certain tasks, can you find the task which uses a bitbake log called bbfatal?
   
Answer
The task is do_banish_unwanted


Can you identify the common variables in the recipes, maybe there is a comment somewhere.
   
hint
Pay Close attention

   
Answer
The SRC_URI, 'S', 'BUILD_DIR', 'D', 'WORKDIR', 'DEPLOY_DIR_IMAGE'


Class files (.bbclass) contain information that is useful to share between recipes files. Similar to OOPs concepts, you can inherit a class between multiple recipes.

Which command is used to read values from a class?

hint
Look at the recipe.
   
Answer
inherit


What happens when you include this class in your recipe?
   
hint
how does inheritance work in C++?

   
Answer
recipe gets a new function and some more metadata.



also a way to share info between recipe but different than class.

How is it different than a class?
   
hint
look at the way its used in the recipe and also on the composition of the include file.

   
Answer
'include' is used to include the file and it cannot have 'functions'



Appends can be identified by the .bbappend extension.
Appends are used to extend a recipe. I.e add more info to an existing recipe.

Why do we need an append? Why don't we modify the .bb file instead?
   
hint
Do we always have access to a recipe?

   
Answer
When we don't have access to a recipe's source code, we need to append a recipe and add our configurations to it!


There are two append files here, Maybe there is someother recipe somewhere, can you guess what its name might be?
   
hint
What does the name of the file indicate?
       Answer    Spell is the new recipe.

What does the bbappend for the initial recipe that we worked with earlier do?

Answer
it tries to create change the variable PR and sets it to "r2"

Conf files are used to set some configurations. Now we will look at a special conf called layer.conf about which we will learn later.

go to ~/work/poky/poky/meta-poky and try to read this file!
What are the bitbake specific METADATA here?

Answer
BBFILE_PRIORITY, BBFILE_COLLECTIONS, BBPATH, BBFILES, BBFILE_PATTERN

item.title: Exercise: Create a recipe
item.description:
Learn different ways of creating a recipe.
Learn how to add a task to a recipe that performs a certain action
Learn how to create a bitbake class
Learn the difference between an inc and bbclass



Go to the folder meta-exercises.
You will find a folder called recipes-createrecipes, ignore the pun.
Inside this is there is a simple recipe called reference.bb and a complex recipe called apache2_2.4.62.bb. Irrespective of their size, the core elements you need in a recipe is
SUMMARY, DESCRIPTION and LICENSE.
Copy the reference.bb recipe and create your own recipe file and name this file as manualrecipe.bb. Remember the recipe should have its own folder, so it should be /recipes-createrecipes/manualrecipe/manualrecipe.bb.
Try to run this new recipe using the command bitbake manualrecipe, your simple recipe is now ready!!


We can create a new recipe with recipestool by using the syntax below.
Syntax : recipetool create -o OUTFILE source
Create a new folder called inventory

go to the inventory folder.
In the syntax above replace OUTFILE with inventory.bb and add the source as https://github.com/sridharsabarish/easyInventory.git. This would create a simple recipe, with information of the source populated.
   
Solution
- recipetool create -o inventory.bb https://github.com/sridharsabarish/easyInventory.git



Create a recipe using devtool using the steps below

Create a directory called devtoolrecipe
Run the following command
devtool add <Recipename> .
This would create a recipe that can be found in the home/yocto/work/poky/poky/build/workspace/recipes/ directory, move this recipe to the folder created earlier.
   
Solution
- devtool add devtoolrecipe .



Add some metadata to the recipe manualrecipe.bb, add the following
PV = "1.0+git${SRCPV}" PR = "r1" # Custom metadata RING_INSCRIPTION = "One ring to rule them all, one ring to find them, one ring to bring them all, and in the darkness bind them" MIDDLE_EARTH_REGION = "The Shire" ENEMY_NAME = "Sauron" ENEMY_DOMAIN = "Mordor"

Now, we will add some tasks to our recipe. The tasks structure is provided for you, can you add them to your recipe.
Remember you need to explicitly add your task!
do_nameoftask( ){ --- some content---- } addtask nameoftask after <someothertask> // You could replace <somothertask> with install, compile, build etc.

Go to the manualrecipe.bb and add two tasks do_display_banner() and do_print_message()

do_display_banner() { bbplain "*********************************************************************************************" bbplain "* *" bbplain "* Example recipe created by Golem *" bbplain "* *" bbplain "* Version: ${PV} *" bbplain "* Revision: ${PR} *" bbplain "* License: ${LICENSE} *" bbplain "* ${RING_INSCRIPTION} *" bbplain "* ${MIDDLE_EARTH_REGION} *" bbplain "* Enemy: ${ENEMY_NAME} of ${ENEMY_DOMAIN} *" bbplain "* *" bbplain "*********************************************************************************************" }

do_print_message() { bbplain "This is a message from do_print_message()" bbplain "${RING_INSCRIPTION}" bbplain "${MIDDLE_EARTH_REGION}" bbplain "Beware of ${ENEMY_NAME} from ${ENEMY_DOMAIN}" }

Add the print statements inside them both you can use bbwarn, bberror to give the statements too.
The syntax is usually bbtype "message", where bbtype is bbwarn, bberror, bbnote, bbfatal and so on.
Note: Remember you need to explicitly add the tasks using addtask command, so add the two tasks before build.


Create a new file called lor.bbclass and put it under the classes directory
Move the two tasks created to this file including the statements used to addthetask


Inherit the class in our manualrecipe.bb this should bring the functions back to the class and try to print them.
   
Answer
- add inherit lor to you manualrecipe.bb file


Optional : Also you could inherit this class to the other recipes created too. (optionally)


Create a folder called include under the layer's conf directory
Now create a file called lor.inc

Now try include the content of the metadata using the include directive in the recipe.

Answer
- add require conf/include/lor.inc to you manualrecipe.bb file
This way by using includes and classes, we can organize our codes and improve readability and reusability.

item.title: Exercise : Package Management, Feeds and so on
item.description:
Understand how to set package-versioning, revision and epoch and when it is appropriate to do so.
Learn how to deal with package dependencies.
Understand the different package formats supports in Yocto.
Learn how to create package groups
Learn how to setup a package feed


Go to a meta-exercises/recipes-packaging and look at the exercise1.
1. What is the Package Name $PN ?
2. What is the Package Version $PV?
3. What is the Package Revision $PR that is used in this Recipe?
4. What is the Package Epoch $PE of this recipe and can it be a floating point?

hint
How is a recipe defined?
   
Answer
- A recipe typically follows this pattern {PN}-{PV}
- The PE And PR values are defined inside the .bb file.
- PN is exercise1
- PV is 1.1
- PR is r11
- PE is 2, not it cannot be a floating point. It has to be a decimal.
## Part 2: Change the packaging 2. When you build this recipe using `bitbake packages1` which one do you think gets executed?
   
hint
What is the order of precedence base on the values of PE , PR , PV?
       Answer    PE has the highest priority, so the recipe with PE 2 which is packages1_1.20.bb would get executed.

Now, take the packages1_1.10 and change the PR="2.0" and try to build now. Do you think this will get built now?
   
hint
Is it higher prio than E?
       Answer    No it wont' get executed.

What happens when you set "PE" to 3 in packages1_1.10?

Answer
Now since the PE is higher than the one for packages1_1.20 it will get executed.
Create a bbappend file called packages1.bbappend that would set the PE="4" Do you think this would have an impact on the other packages we have?
   

hint
Appends also can be version controlled!
       Answer    It would impact the packages1.bb only, since the append is made for that. so now Packages1.bb's function would run!

What would happen if you change the bbappend to packages1%.bbappend?
Make the package automatically update its version packages > Updating Package Version



Go to the packages2 folder and try to add a dependency to a recipe called magic and try to build this recipe. Do you see something strange?
   
hint
how is a dependency added
       Answer    `DEPENDS += "magic"` ### Solving Dependency. 9. In `packages3` folder there is a recipe called packages3.bb, try to rename it to `magic.bb` and try to run `bitbake packages2`, what do you see now? 10. Now rename the file `magic.bb` back to `packages3.bb`. A recipe can solve another recipe's dependency, maybe there is something hidden in the comments that would solve this issue?Once this recipe satisfies that package, the dependency would be solved.



Can you enable support for deb
   
hint
Maybe local.conf has some information
       Answer    add this to the recipe    `PACKAGE_CLASSES:append = “ package_deb”`


Objective create a local package feed and host it in a python server!


use bitbake package-index after building all packages, otherwise package index will not include them
cd build /tmp/deploy/rpm
python3 -m http.server 5678


List all the packages that are available in our build.
   
Answer
Use the first command from below.


Which of these packages have just one file and have no extra files with them?
Bash
strace
`time
socat
iptables
Are they just binaries or do they have other files with them?
   
Answer
run oe-pkgdata-utils list-pkg-files
Only time and bash have just one files.


Which of the above 5 packages have a revision whose first two values are same?

Answer
- use oe-pkgdata-util package-info
- we can see that iptables and socat share similar version numbers.

item.title: Exercise 7: Yocto Customizing Recipe
item.description:
Learn how to extend an existing Recipe with a .bbappend file
Learn how to create a patch for your recipe.
Learn how to add package configuration to your recipes.


How can you find what recipes have been appended?

Run this command bitbake-layers show-appends
This would show you a list of all the recipes that has been appended!


Go to recipes-extendrecipe/appendexample, here there is a recipe which doesn't have a license. There are some instructions available.
Go to home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta/files/common-licenses
Search for the license type and run md5sum license for example md5sum MIT
or you can find the license in your layer with COPYING.MIT
A license is needed for a recipe, otherwise QA will throw an error.
We can find most licenses under work/poky/poky/meta/files/common-licenses also referred to as COMMON_LICENSE_DIR
Here is a simple starter for how to add to your .bb file
LIC = "MIT" LIC_FILES_CHKSUM = "file://${COMMON_LICENSE_DIR}/MIT;md5=0835ade698e0bcf8506ecda2f7b4f302"

Based on this can you add the license GPLv2.0 to it?


Go to /home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta-exercises/recipes-extendrecipe/firstrec

Create an append file for this recipe. How should it be named?

Answer
firstrec.bbappend
Inside the append file modify the values of the following variables.

Set PR to r12
Set PE to 4
Update the value for CAT1, CAT2 and CAT3 to as you feel like.

Now try to run bitbake -e first | grep "^CAT1" , similarly for other variables to double check.

Answer
You will now see that the append file overwrote the normal recipe.


We can modify a recipe's source by making patches. A patch is simply a diff that is made in a file.
There is a patch file which is present in the files folder.

What does it do?

Hint
How would a git diff looks like?
   
Answer
The patch creates a new shell script called somescript.sh which runs the commands ifconfig, nproc and free.


Now, lets include it to the recipe. Which variable do we modify?
   
Hint
'Check the hints on the .bb file'
       Answer    SRC_URI


Apart from changing Metadata, a recipe's task can also be extended.
Usually the trick is to add the :append override to the task and now we can append a task.

In the .bbappend file create a task which is a copy of the task in the .bb file, but add the append override to it . Change the text in the print to say "Example from BBappend"
Now try to build the recipe and see what gets printed.      Answer    You will note that first bbfile is run, then the task in the bbappend file is run!!
Now try to create a new task in the .bbappend with the prepend override, change the texts to example from prepend and run this again!
Now try to build it a few more times and you will notice that you don't see any output!
How can we make a task run explicitly?
   
Hint
bitbake -C can help us run a task

   
Solution
bitbake -C display_banner firstrec
   


Now we will create a .c file with the following information
#include <stdio.h> int main() { printf("Hello Yocto!\n"); return 0; }

Save this as hello.c

Populate our recipe firstrec.bb or firtrec.bbappend with two tasks do_install and do_compile with the following info
do_compile() { ${CC} ${CFLAGS} ${LDFLAGS} hello.c -o hello } do_install() { install -d ${D}${base_bindir} install -m 0755 ${UNPACKDIR}/hello ${D}${base_bindir} }
Install -d creates a new directory and the {base_bindir} corresponds to /bin
install -m copies the binary to the /bin to the /bin folder
Ensure we have this also in our recipe in the future, this is relevant for the latest yocto version. I have added it by default.
S = "${WORKDIR}/sources" UNPACKDIR = "${S}"

Usually we need to add one extra variable to make sure that the files are detected in the path.
FILESEXTRAPATHS:prepend := "${THISDIR}/files:"
Remember to use this as well in your future recipes!

Now its time to include this file! Can you add this file also to our recipe?
   
Hint
- This is similar to adding a patch!

   
Answer
SRC_URI += "file://hello.c"


Now try to explore the pkg using oe-pkg-data util what do you see?
   
Answer
You can see the binary /bin/hello



Package configs are used to customize a recipe.
Like control some behaviours like run time dependency, build time dependency and so forth.
You can check what it means here, but don't take too long :P
Open home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta-exercises/recipes-extendrecipe

There is a recipe packageconfigexample.bb here which is causing some mayhem. Can you try building it?
   
Hint
- What are the six attributes used in a packageconfig definiton?

   
Answers
- There is a dependency to magical, which is causing errors!


Now try to commenting line 18 and uncomment line 20, what happens now?
   
Answers
- There is a new runtime dependency, this doesn't look good.


Now comment line 20 and uncomment line 19 and see what happens!

Try commenting and uncommenting thee "PACKAGECONFIG ??" varaible maybe you will understand what is going on here!
   
Answers
- The dependencies are now met as there is a troubleshooting.bb file, so the error goes away!

Note how by just changing the value of the package config variable, we can make the recipe behave differently!

item.title: Exercise : Create a layer
item.description:
Learn how layers work in Yocto
Learn how to create a new layer in Yocto
Learn how to include several recipes to this layer
Learn how the layer.conf file works.

bitbake-layers is a powerful command, it can do almost everything we want with layers.


Identify what layers we have in the current poky build!
- bitbake-layers show-layers
There is a file which keeps track of these layers, do you which one it it is?

hint
bblayers.conf

Explore The bitabake-layers command and find which command helps us make a new layer. hint The help documentation gives us an hint
answer `bitbake-layers create-layer` is used to create a new layer


Start by cd ~/work/poky/poky and try to create a new layer called meta-layer1.
Now to try the bitbake-layers show-layers command. What do you see?
You will notice that this layer has not been added. This has to be added manually by bitbake-layers add-layers command. So add the layer.
We want the layer to have a value for priority that is bigger than the other layers, can you find how to do that?
hint There is a file inside this layer which can be used to set the priority!
Answer - look for the file `layer.conf` inside the `conf` folder. - Here we can set the priority using `BBFILE_PRIORITY_meta-layer1 = "100"`

Go to the example.bb in this layer and modify the text in the do_display_banner as Example layer 1 recipe created by bitbake-layers.


Now go back to cd ~/work/poky/poky and create a new layer called meta-layer2 without changing the default values. Modify the example.bb by adding the text Example layer 2 recipe created by bitbake-layers
Try to build this recipe using bitbake example and see what you get as output!
hint How does priority affect a layer?
Answer - The layer with highest prio is executed, so our recipe in layer1 with priority 100 is executed instead of the newly created layer.


Create a new layer called meta-layer3

Move the recipe from /home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta-layer3/recipes-example/example to /home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta-layer3/recipes-example/ and rename it as layer3.bb
Try to build this recipe? Does it work? hint Is it in our path?
answer It wouldn't work as the location is not our BBFILE path! 11. Maybe there is a way to to solve this? Can you find and edit the metadata in `layer.conf` that could solve this mess? Once done, try building the recipe again! hint we are dealing with files right?
answer Remove the one extra /* in the bbfiles this would make it possible to soearch the recipe in our folder. `BBFILES += "${LAYERDIR}/recipes-*/*.bb \ ${LAYERDIR}/recipes-*/*.bbappend"`



Now its time to remove layer3 and layer 1. What command can we use? hint its also a bitbake-layers command Answer `bitbake-layers remove-layer meta-layer1` `bitbake-layers remove-layer meta-layer3`
What happens when you build now? hint Where can i find example.bb? Answer Example.bb is only found in layer2 so it is executed!
Which of the following is true?
If there is just one recipe, but it is in a layer with low priority it is not executed?
If there are multiple recipes, then the recipe from the highest prioirty layer is executed?
If there are multiple recipes, then the recipe with the higest epoch/version is executed irrespective of layer priority?
If a layer has lower priority, even the recipes which are not found in other layers are also not executed.
If there is just one recipe in all the layers, then it is executed no matter what!

item.title: Exercise : Images
item.description:
Learn how to build an image with specific constraints
Choose the Image Filesystem
Choose the rootfs size
Add specific packages and remove some packages from the image.


A Yocto image is a custom Linux system built for embedded devices, created using the Yocto Project.
It combines the Linux kernel, essential software, and settings into one ready-to-use package.
You can tailor the image to include only the software and features you need, making it lightweight and efficient for specific hardware.
The Yocto build system makes it easy to select what goes into the image, ensuring it’s optimized for performance.
Once built, the image can be installed on devices, offering a stable and flexible solution for embedded projects.

If you recollect, when we worked with source oe-init-build-env, the text displayed certain images that we could "bake" which looked like "core-image-*".

An image looks like a recip,  Which one of these images do you not see when you source oe-init-build-env?
1. core-image-weston
2. core-image-full-cmdline
3. core-image-x12
4. core-image-sato
5. core-image-minimal
   
Answer
core-image-x12 doesn't exists
2. We can take an existing image recipe for inspirtation. Can you find out where we can find the source for `core-image-minimal.bb`?        hint    -    What linux command is useful for recursively finding a file? Maybe we can try this on the poky directory ~/work/poky/poky        Answer     Try `find . -name "core-image-minimal*.*"` this would give us ` /meta/recipes-core/images/` as the location.


In this recipe, can you identify what is the size of the Root File System and if there are any extra space allocated to it?
   
hint
- Is there any metadata that looks like it could be for Rootfile System?

   
Answer
IMAGE_ROOTFS_SIZE and IMAGE_ROOTFS_EXTRA_SPACE are used for this. Here the size is 8GB for ROOTFS with 4GB of extra space/


How are the packages installed in this image?
   
hint
- Is there any metadata that could "INSTALL" additional Packages?

   
Answer
- IMAGE_INSTALL is used to install packages. In this case we use something called packagegroups!


We will now create a custom image, it is always a good practice to create our image from a smaller image such as core-image-minimal or core-image-base.

Create a folder called recipes-images and create a new blank recipe called myimage.bb, remember to place the image.bb under myimage folder!
We can use the core-image-minimal as base, how can you add it to your recipe?      hint    You can use `require` directive to accomplish this!    Answer    Add this line to your recipe `require recipes-core/images/core-image-minimal.bb`
Creating our own image recipe allows us to change the Image Filesystem Type? we can try to set our file system to "ext4 ext3", how can we do that?    hint    You can use `IMAGE_FSTYPE` metadata to accomplish this!    Answer    Set IMAGE_FSTYPE="ext4 ext3"
 
 
8. Now add the line that sets the size of root file system to 1gb
   Answer   IMAGE_ROOTFS_SIZE = "1024"


Add support for the strace packages to our image and build our image! Might take around 5mins.    Answer   IMAGE_INSTALL += "strace"
Build the image and Run qemu. Can you use the command strace inside the shell?
runqemu ~/work/poky/poky/build/tmp/deploy/images/qemux86-64/myimage-qemux86-64.rootfs.ext4 nographic

What happens when you type apt? can you use it? Add support for apt and build again!    Answer   IMAGE_INSTALL += "apt"
10 . Now Add support for openssh
   Answer   IMAGE_INSTALL += "openssh"

package Group

Package group as the name suggest, help to group packages together so that we can add them easily to our images/recipes as needed.


Go to /home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta/recipes-extended/packagegroups
Explore the packages group used by the core-image-full-cmdline.bb
How many types of package group does this recipe use?
   Answer - 7 different types `packagegroup-core-full-cmdline` `packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-utils` `packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-extended ` `packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-dev-utils ` `packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-multiuser ` `packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-initscripts ` `packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-sys-services `

This is a good resource to learn how to add package groups to our recipes!

item.title: Exercise on Troubleshooting
item.description:
Learn common troubleshooting strategies
Learn when to how to add logging to recipes 10. Troubleshooting > Part 1 Adding Logs to Recipes
Learn how to debug metadata variables. 10. Troubleshooting > Part 2 Debugging Metadata
Learn how to inspect a package using oe-pkg-data util 10. Troubleshooting > Part 3 Inspecting a package
Learn how to generate dependency graphs and view dependecy 10. Troubleshooting > Part 4 Dependency Graph
Learn how to use devshell
Lean how to enable GNU Debugger

Troubleshooting will an inevitable part of your yocto journey. Chances are you will be working with recipes and configuration files created others and it is crucial to understand how to debug when things go haywire.
But first, lets start with the simplest thing that you could do when it comes to troubleshooting, a.k.a logging i.e adding traces.

We covered some examples previously, can you uncover what types of logs we can use in our recipes?

Answer
bberror, bbfatal, bbwarn, bbnote,bbplain, bbdebug
There are tasks in python and some using the normal syntax, how does logging change when you use python instead of the normal syntax?

Hint
its a minor difference
   
Answer
bberror, bbfatal, bbwarn, bbnote,bbplain, bbdebug is used in general case, however
python uses 'bb.error() bb.fatal()' and so on.


There are so many places where a metadata could be updated so looking at a .bb files is not always enough!
Take core-image-full-cmdline for example, this recipe, is used to build our very first image. Can you find out what are the values for the following here?
SRC_URI IMAGE_INSTALL WORKDIR DISTRO for this one?
Lets say we want to find all Packages are used in e` how can we do that by debugging?
   
Hint
Can we use the bitbake env?

   
Answer
bitbake -e core-image-full-cmdline | grep "^IMAGE_INSTALL="
This would give us the package groups used! Similarly we can find the other Values.


Imagine, being handed a big system and you have to now find all recipes and pacakges that are installed here, how can we find that?
   
Hint
Maybe we covered something in the previous exercises!

   
Answer
oe-pkg-data-util can be used!



Chances are you will run a recipe, the recipe will not throw any message, but that doesn't mean there are no logs! Where can you find the logs?

Answer
we can find it under the tmp/work directory like this for example.
/home/yocto/work/poky/poky/build/tmp/work/core2-64-poky-linux/firstrec/1.0/temp/log.do_compile.21507
Maybe your recipe has dependencies, there could be a easy way to identify dependencies between recipes. What can you do to find dependencies of a recipe?
   
Answer
Explore the dependency graph!



How can you find dependencies of a recipe?

Answer
Explore the dependency graph!
bitbake -g -u taskexp_ncurses recipe_name
Can you use this idea to find dependencies for the recipes bash and strace
   
Answer
Explore the dependency graph!
bitbake -g -u taskexp_ncurses strace
bitbake -g -u taskexp_ncurses bash
## Part 2 - Troubleshooting! - This next segment is an actual experience of troubleshooting with Yocto. - You have a bunch of recipes under `meta-exercises/recipes-troubleshooting`, the objective if time permits is to get them to work! 8. Run `bitbake troubleshooting` and other recipes!! * Solutions can be found in `meta-solution`


Finally, in yocto we can enable support for extra debugging, and one such use case is the GDB.
Read the local.conf and enable support for GDB.
Build the core-image-full-cmdline, boot the image using runqemu core-image-full-cmdline nographic and try to run gdb in the shell when it boots in qemu.

item.title: Exercise: Devtool, Create a patch
item.description:
Learn how to use Devtool
Explore more of the extended SDK.
Devtool  is part of the extended SDK. Extended SDK makes it relatively easier to work with patches and other stuff.


What devtool command can you use to extract a recipe?
   
hint
Read the devtool help text
     Answer `devtool modify` is used to extract a recipe

Once extracted, where can you find the source code of the recipe?

Answer
/home/yocto/work/poky/poky/build/workspace/sources/
Which variables in recipe metadata should we modify to add a patch to a recipe?

Answer
- SRC_URI should be updated with the patch details to include it in our recipe.


Now we need to extract the linux kernel? Can you find how it looks like?

Answer
- devtool modify linux-yocto The command will extract the recipe to `/home/yocto/work/poky/poky/build/workspace/sources/`
Open this location in VSCODE and see how the kernel source code looks like!!


Changes can be made to the recipe's source code.
For the sake of this exercise, we will add some comments to the kernel's source.

Try adding some comments to these files below and more if you feel like.
Makefile`
driver/amba/bus.c `
drivers/fpga/altera-cvp.c
Check the git status, you will note the modified files!


Like bitbake devtool can also be used for building a recipe. The command used to do this is devtool build recipe-name

So try to build the changes with devtool for linux-yocto recipe
 
Answer
- devtool build linux-yocto



Now try to add these changes using git add .
Its time to commit, give an appropriate message using the command
git commit -m message

Generate the patch using

devtool update-recipe linux-yocto


This would create a patch and update the recipe, note the name of the recipe at the end of the process.

Go to /home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta/recipes-kernel/linux . Can you find this file? and is it added to our SRC_URI?

Devtool is super nice, it would create a patch and automatically update it in our recipe.

How does the patch file look like? What info can you infer from it?



`devtool find-recipe recipename will find a recipe.

Can you use devtool tool find where the inventory recipe is located?
How about the recipe bbexample

devtool rename recipe
13. Rename the recipe bbexmple to newexample using devtool!

item.title: Exercise 11: BSP & Kernel Modifications!
item.description:
Explore the existing BSP layers in Yocto
Learn how to find more BSPs!
Learn how to modify the linux kernel

A Board Support Package (BSP) is a collection of information that defines how to support a particular hardware device, set of devices, or hardware platform. We can create a layer to keep recipes and other metadata related to this information. Usually this is done by the Vendor of a board and we can ususally find the Board support here https://layers.openembedded.org/
In the image below we see the source for these layers and it is just a matter of cloning these layers and adding to our yocto build.


If i want to include support for NVIDIA Tegra processors which layer should i be downloading?
   
hint
type nvidia tegra in the search with layers
     Answer `meta-tegra` is the needed layer! ## Part 2 : Exploring existing BSP layers 2. In our yocto build, we have used the `meta-yocto-bsp` layer from this layer can you find out what machines are already supported by us?        hint    Maybe the directory structure of `conf` can give a hint?      Answer `beaglebone-yocto`, `genericarm64`. `genericx86-64` and `genericx86`

But wait, aren't we using qemux86-64 for our builds, where does that come from?    hint    Are there only one bsp layers?      Answer check `home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta/conf/machine`


Once we have the layers in place with the conf for each machine, how do we build for the machine? Maybe the local.conf has some clue?

Answer
MACHINE variable needs to be set
If i have beagle-bone board and i want to build for this machine, what should i set the metadata to?

Answer
MACHINE="beaglebone-yocto"
There are a lots of variables that can be used for configuring the machine specific metadata, which of the following is not a machine variable? SERIAL_CONSOLES , KERNEL_IMAGETYPE , MACHINEOVERRIDES, TUNE_ARCH, MACHINE_FEATURES, MACHINE_INSTALLS, PREFERRED_PROVIDER
 
Hint
When in doubt check!
https://docs.yoctoproject.org/ref-manual/variables.html

 
Answer
MACHINE_INSTALLS


In this segment, we will cover minor details on how to modify the kernel using kernel fragments.
You can refer to the kernel manual for help

Run this command
bitbake virtual/kernel -c menuconfig

Go to Networking Support and enable the CAN bus subsystem support
Feel free to enable more setting as you like.
Now go the exit option and keep exiting.
At the end it will ask you to save like the image below, choose the yes option


Exit the menu config
Run diffconfig to generate the fragment
bitbake virtual/kernel -c diffconfig

Inspect the fragment and see what it does
Optionally: Add the fragment to your kernel recipe. Similar to adding a patch!

item.title: Exercise 9: Best Practices
item.description:
Lean how to identify what licenses are being used by what recipe.
Learn how to satisfy Copy-left /GPLv3 Compliance
Best practices such as
Creating a custom Distro
Enabling build-info
Using Extended SDK
Reducing the number of layers.


Being aware of licensing is crucial to avoid any potential copyright issues when we develop software.

Poky being a good Samaritan builds the license manifest in a specific folder can you identify which folder it is ?
   
hint
Maybe it is somwhere inside the tmp folder?
     Answer `~/work/poky/poky/build/tmp/deploy/license` is where we find licensing information for all the packages!

If lets say i want to a recipe to my commercial build which of the following license should i be careful about? GPL-2.0-only, GPL-3.0-or-later, MIT, Apache-2.0

Answer
GPL-3.0 or later is dangerous
If i am creating a new recipe and i want to give a different license to it. Where can i find the md5sum for the license that is needed by the LIC_FILE_CHKSUM metadata?
   
hint
check the meta layer
     Answer - /home/yocto/work/poky/poky/meta/files/common-licenses - and then we can run md5sum


In the meta-exercises/recipes-licensing, i have created a bash file findLicenses.sh which would could roughly help us get an idea of licenses included in a package. This takes the name of the license as an argument.

Can you find the recipes which have MIT license with it?
 
Answer
- ./findLicenses MIT



How about the packages that are potentially problematic such as GPL-3.0or LGPL for commercial use?

Answer
- ./findLicenses GPL-3.0

Copy left project have the following obligation

The source code of the project
The license for the project
Any modification to the project
Any script that is required to configure and build

How can we provide the source code for the project?
   
hint
we inherit something
     Answer - `INHERIT += "archiver"` - `ARCHIVER_MODE[src] = "original"` 7. How can we provide the source modifications?
 
Answer
- ARCHIVER_MODE[src] = "patched"


How can we provide the licensing text?

Answer
- COPY_LIC_MANIFEST = "1"
- 'COPY_LIC_DIRS = "1"'`


Until now, we have been violating a best practice that has been so obvious. This is a violation that makes us loose all our data if there is an update to our code. What can we do to mitigate this mistake?

hint
Is all our metadata versioncontrolled?      Answer - Local.conf is not version controlled, so we should remove the changes from local.conf and isntead move it our distro and image recipes instead!
Poky is a great source of reference, can we just use poky to build our images?
   
hint
Look at the Learning outcome
     Answer We have to transition to a custom distro and we cannot use poky as it has a lot of unnecessary packages.

Poky gave us two of the best practices for free and we didn't even have to look for them. One was the buildinfo and the other bill of materials, how can we enable them in our custom distro?

Answer
INHERIT += "create-spdx"
inherit image-buildinfo



Devtool is part of the extended sdk, what are included in the original standard SDK?
 
Answer
QEMU
bitbake




Imagine you are now a yocto developer who is working on building an image for raspberry pi, you find the recipes you need, should you create new layers for each of the raspberry variant or should you use the existing layers?

item.title: Exercise : Create your own Custom Distro
item.description:
Learn how to add distro features to your image
Learn how to create your own distro.

Distro layers are used to define information about a Linux Distro
A typical distro layer looks like this.
├── distro │   ├── include │   │   ├──someincludes.inc │   │   ├── someinclude2inc │   ├── distro1.conf │   ├──distro2.conf ├── layer.conf

There are several distros that are provided to us by the meta-poky layer. Can you find them all?

Answer
- The distros are poky,poky-tiny,poky-altcfg,poky-bleeding
Which of these distros will require opkg to install its packages?

hint
Try to find which packge format uses opkg as its package manager?        Answer    - `opkg` is used by `ipk` formats    - in `poky-altcfg.conf` ithe `PACKAGE_CLASSES` is set to `package_ipk`
What does DISTROOVERRIDES in line 36 of poky-tiny.conf do?

hint
Check here        Answer    - Basically it sets the default value of the OVERRIDES variable to poky and poky tiny. so we can basically define metatdata with poky-tiny override and it it would work right out of the box!
Does poky-tiny use the same kernel as the poky-bleeding?

hint
What does PREFERRED_PROVIDER do?        Answer    - In `poky-tiny.conf`, preferred provider is used to set the `linux-yocto-tiny` as its kernel, so no they are not using the same kernel!!
How can one add support for wifi in poky-tiny?

hint
Maybe the comments help?        Answer    - Setting the `DISTRO_FEATURES_WIFI = "Wifi" `would enable wifi in poky-tiny!!
which of the distribution supports systemd?

hint
Try grepping for systemd        Answer    - In `poky-altcfg.conf` we can see that if the musl override is not set, we can use systemd with `poky-altcfg` distro!!


Now that we know how a distro looks like, can you create a new distro called afry, note this should be in a new layer.

hint
Use bitbake-layers to create new layer. How is a layer named in yocto?        Answer    - `bitbake-layers create-layer meta-afry`    - `bitbake-layer add-layer meta-afry`
Now create the directory structure for a distro.

hint
How does poky distros look like?        Answer    - inside `conf` create a directory called `distro`
You should create a .conf file , how should it be named?

hint
Maybe this is the name of the distro. How do we want to name our distro?        Answer    - it should be `afry.conf`
Create the Base for the distro from Poky.conf

hint
Should we always copy? or is there a simpler way out?        Answer    - Add this line to your conf file!     `require conf/distro/poky.conf`
Using Poky or poky-tiny as reference can you populate the following for our distro?
1. Name of the distro?
2. What are its overrides by default?
3. What is its version?
4. Any code names?

hint
What variables does poky use?        Answer - `DISTRO= "afry"` - `DISTRO_NAME = "AFRY"` - `DISTROOVERRIDES = "poky:afry"` - `DISTRO_VERSION = "1.0.0"` - `DISTRO_CODENAME = "makingfuture"`

Note : Remember to create Software Bill of material, poky inherits this by default but good to keep in mind.
INHERIT += "create-spdx"

Note : Building a new architecture/distro in this machine would cause two issues

Storage Space issues
delete the previous created images and files. So if you want to refer and retry this material at home, don't use this VM.

If you decide to use this VM for this challenge, you could delete /build/tmp/work folder. This would give you space to build. However the new build would take 6 hours.
So it is recommended to try this capstone challenge in a separate machine later.

For now just think about how you can do this!!

Create a linux distribution
Architecture : It should be for qemuarm architecture.
Root file system should be 10GB and should have an extra space of 1gb.
Packages : Apart from the base packages, we need the following package
packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-utils
packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-multiuser
packagegroup-core-full-cmdline-dev-utils
Hint : Remember to check how core-image-full-cmdline add the packaging support. This has to do with package groups and you need to create your own image.
Recipes and layers: There should be atleast 2 layers and 3 recipes in each of these layers and the recipe should create a file in your home folder.
Customization : Use package config to enable a dependency between your recipe.
All these recipes are to be present in this image, find a way to verify this.
Kernel : Try to modify the kernel setttings, generate a cfg fragment and include the fragment. Some examples inlude support for CAN Bus. Be creative.
DISTRO : A custom distro should be used. We can go with "afry" distro created in the previous section.
Pacakaging support : It should have the following package support
npm
deb
ipk
Troubleshooting : Enable GDB and also include support for profiling.


Change the value of DISTRO to afry here. otherwise poky will be used as the distro from local.conf
5. This would make sure that the new distro is used for the new builds.
Now you are ready. Build it up. Take a nap, it should be done over night!! Good luck!!
